title: Management of Iliac Artery Occlusive Disease

procedures.name: Adult. Nonsmoker, sedentary lifestyle. Left lower-extremity claudication on walking, asymmetrically diminished left femoral pulse. No symptoms at rest. Initial management.
Risk factor analysis and lipid profile and ABIs
Antiplatelet adjunctive therapy
US duplex Doppler lower extremity
CTA abdomen and pelvis with bilateral lower extremity runoff with IV contrast
MRA abdomen and pelvis with bilateral lower extremity runoff with IV contrast
Plethysmography and pulse volume recording
Catheter-directed angiography
Anticoagulation adjunctive therapy
Adult. Long history of claudication. Acute-onset left lower-extremity pain. Absent left femoral pulse by palpation, faint audible DP and PT Doppler signals. Initial management.
CTA abdomen and pelvis with bilateral lower extremity runoff with IV contrast
Catheter-directed angiography
MRA abdomen and pelvis with bilateral lower extremity runoff with IV contrast
US duplex Doppler lower extremity
Ankle brachial index
Risk factor analysis and lipid profile
Plethysmography and pulse volume recording

Adult. Known atrial fibrillation and spine surgery performed within the past month. Sudden-onset right lower-extremity pain. Diminished pulses in right lower extremity. CTA demonstrates isolated filling defect in right common iliac artery. Initial therapy.
Catheter-directed mechanical thrombectomy
Surgical  revascularization
Antiplatelet adjunctive therapy
Catheter-directed thrombolytic therapy
Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty iliac artery
Primary stent placement iliac artery
Adult. Past medical history of heavy smoking. Severe claudication without rest pain. CTA demonstrates bilateral common iliac artery stenosis at or greater than 90% (TASC A). Initial therapy.
Best medical management including supervised exercise program
Bilateral primary stent placement iliac artery
Anticoagulation adjunctive therapy
Bilateral percutaneous transluminal angioplasty iliac artery
Surgical  revascularization

Adult. Past medical history significant for diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and smoking. Increasing claudication of right lower-extremity involving right buttock for the last 3 months. CTA pelvis with runoff reveals short-segment occlusion of the right common iliac artery (TASC B). Initial therapy.
Best medical management including supervised exercise program
Primary stent placement aortoiliac arterial segment
Anticoagulation adjunctive therapy
Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty aortoiliac arterial segment
Surgical  revascularization

Adult. Past medical history significant for diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and heavy smoking. Gradually increasing claudication of bilateral lower extremities for at least 2 months. CTA pelvis with runoff reveals bilateral common iliac artery occlusion without any involvement of the external or internal iliac artery (TASC C). Initial therapy.
Best medical management including supervised exercise program
Anticoagulation adjunctive therapy
Bilateral primary stent placement aortoiliac arterial segment
Bilateral percutaneous transluminal angioplasty aortoiliac arterial segment
Surgical  revascularization

Adult. Worsening claudication and small ischemic ulcers on digits of both feet. CTA demonstrates diffuse atherosclerosis involving distal aorta and both common and external iliac arteries with multiple stenoses at or greater than 50%, bilateral mid-superficial femoral artery stenoses at or greater than 70% with 2-vessel tibial runoff bilaterally (TASC D). Initial therapy.
Percutaneous stent placement aortoiliac arterial segment plus superficial femoral
Antiplatelet adjunctive therapy
Surgical  revascularization
Percutaneous stent placement aortoiliac arterial segment
Anticoagulation adjunctive therapy
Best medical management including supervised exercise program only
Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty aortoiliac arterial segment
